siteaudit.issue.205.title: No HSTS support
siteaudit.issue.205.desc: About this issue: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs web browsers that they can communicate with servers only through HTTPS connections. So, to ensure that you don't serve unsecured content to your audience, we recommend that you implement HSTS support. How to fix: Use a server that supports HSTS.
siteaudit.issue.205.descAbout: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs web browsers that they can communicate with servers only through HTTPS connections. So, to ensure that you don't serve unsecured content to your audience, we recommend that you implement HSTS support.
siteaudit.issue.205.descFix: Use a server that supports HSTS.
siteaudit.issue.206.title: Orphaned pages (Google Analytics)
siteaudit.issue.206.desc: About this issue: A webpage that is not linked to internally is called an orphaned page. It is very important to check your website for such pages. If a page has valuable content but is not linked to by another page on your website, it can miss out on the opportunity to receive enough link juice. Orphaned pages that no longer serve their purpose confuse your users and, as a result, negatively affect their experience. We identify orphaned pages on your website by comparing the number of pages we crawled to the number of pages in your Google Analytics account. That's why to check your website for any orphaned pages, you need to connect your Google Analytics account. How to fix: Review all orphaned pages on your website and do either of the following: 1. If a page is no longer needed, remove it. 2. If a page has valuable content and brings traffic to your website, link to it from another page on your website. 3. If a page serves a specific need and requires no internal linking, leave it as is

siteaudit.issue.207.title: Orphaned sitemap pages
siteaudit.issue.207.desc: About this issue: An orphaned page is a webpage that is not linked to internally. Including orphaned pages in your sitemap.xml files is considered to be a bad practice, as these pages will be crawled by search engines. Crawling outdated orphaned pages will waste your crawl budget. If an orphaned page in your sitemap.xml file has valuable content, we recommend that you link to it internally. How to fix: Review all orphaned pages in your sitemap.xml files and do either of the following: If a page is no longer needed, remove it; If a page has valuable content and brings traffic to your website, link to it from another page on your website; If a page serves a specific need and requires no internal linking, leave it as is.
siteaudit.issue.207.descAbout: An orphaned page is a webpage that is not linked to internally. If an orphaned page in your sitemap.xml file has valuable content, we recommend that you link to it internally.
siteaudit.issue.207.descFix:
Review all orphaned pages in your sitemap.xml files and do either of the following:
 - If a page is no longer needed, remove it
 - If a page has valuable content and brings traffic to your website, link to it from another page on your website
 - If a page serves a specific need and requires no internal linking, leave it as is
siteaudit.issue.208.title: Slow avg. document interactive time
siteaudit.issue.208.desc: About this issue: We all know that slow page-load speed negatively affects user experience. However, if a user can start interacting with your webpage within 1 second, they are much less likely to click away from this page. That's why it is important to keep a close eye on the time it takes your most important webpages to become usable, known as the Average Document Interactive Time. For more information, please see Why Performance Matters: https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/why-performance-matters/. To evaluate your site performance, use the Site Performance report. How to fix: Make sure that users can start interacting with your most important pages as quickly as possible.

siteaudit.issue.209.title: Blocked by X-Robots-Tag: noindex HTTP header
siteaudit.issue.209.desc: About this issue: The x-robots-tag is an HTTP header that can be used to instruct search engines whether or not they can index or crawl a webpage. This tag supports the same directives as a regular meta robots tag and is typically used to control the crawling of non-HTML files. If a page is blocked from crawling with x-robots-tag, it will never appear in search results. How to fix: Make sure that pages with valuable content are not blocked from crawling by mistake.

siteaudit.issue.210.title: Blocked external resources in robots.txt
siteaudit.issue.210.desc:
About this issue: Blocked external resources are resources (e.g., CSS, JavaScript, image files, etc.) that are hosted on an external website and blocked from crawling by a "Disallow" directive in an external robots.txt file. Disallowing these files may prevent search engines from accessing them and, as a result, properly rendering and indexing your webpages. This, in return, may lead to lower rankings. For more information, please see this article https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/6153277?hl=en. How to fix: If blocked resources that are hosted on an external website have a strong impact on your website, contact the website owner and ask them to edit their robots.txt file.
If blocked resources are not necessary for your site, simply ignore them.

siteaudit.issue.211.desc: About this issue: If your website uses JavaScript or CSS files that are hosted on an external site, you should be sure that they work properly. Any script that has stopped running on your website may jeopardize your rankings, since search engines will not be able to properly render and index your webpages. Moreover, broken JavaScript and CSS files may cause website errors, and this will certainly spoil your user experience. How to fix: Contact the website owner and ask them to fix a broken file.

siteaudit.issue.212.title: Page Crawl Depth more than 3 clicks
siteaudit.issue.212.desc: About this issue: A page's crawl depth is the number of clicks required for users and search engine crawlers to reach it via its corresponding homepage. From an SEO perspective, an excessive crawl depth may pose a great threat to your optimization efforts, as both crawlers and users are less likely to reach deep pages. For this reason, pages that contain important content should be no more than 3 clicks away from your homepage. How to fix: Make sure that pages with important content can be reached within a few clicks. If any of them are buried too deep in your site, consider changing your internal link architecture.

siteaudit.issue.213.desc: About this issue: Having very few incoming internal links means very few visits, or even none, and fewer chances of placing in search results. It is a good practice to add more incoming internal links to pages with useful content. That way, you can rest assured that users and search engines will never miss them. How to fix: Add more incoming internal links to pages with important content.

siteaudit.issue.214.title: Permanent redirects
siteaudit.issue.214.desc: About this issue: Although using permanent redirects (a 301 or 308 redirect) is appropriate in many situations (for example, when you move a website to a new domain, redirect users from a deleted page to a new one, or handle duplicate content issues), we recommend that you keep them to a reasonable minimum. Every time you redirect one of your website's pages, it decreases your crawl budget, which may run out before search engines can crawl the page you want to be indexed. Moreover, too many permanent redirects can be confusing to users. How to fix: Review all URLs with a permanent redirect. Change permanent redirects to a target page URL where possible.

siteaudit.issue.215.title: Resources formatted as page links
siteaudit.issue.215.desc: About this issue: We detected that some links to resources are formatted with HTML element. An tag with a href attribute is used to link to other webpages and must only contain a page URL. Search engines will crawl your site from page to page by following these HTML page links. When following a page link that contains a resource, for example, an image, the returned page will not contain anything except an image. This may confuse search engines and will indicate that your site has poor architecture. How to fix: Review your links. Replace links with tags necessary for specific resources. For example, if you’d like to add an image, use an tag with an alt attribute describing the contents of your image.
siteaudit.issue.215.descAbout: We detected that some links to resources are formatted with &#60a href&#62 HTML element. An &#60a&#62 tag with a href attribute is used to link to other webpages and must only contain a page URL. Search engines will crawl your site from page to page by following these HTML page links. When following a page link that contains a resource, for example, an image, the returned page will not contain anything except an image. This may confuse search engines and will indicate that your site has poor architecture.
siteaudit.issue.215.descFix: Review your links. Replace &#60a href&#62 links with tags necessary for specific resources. For example, if you’d like to add an image, use an &#60img&#62 tag with an alt attribute describing the contents of your image.

siteaudit.issue.216.title: Links with no anchor text
siteaudit.issue.216.desc: About this issue: This issue is triggered if a link (either external or internal) on your website has an empty or naked anchor (i.e., anchor that uses a raw URL), or anchor text only contains symbols. Although a missing anchor doesn't prevent users and crawlers from following a link, it makes it difficult to understand what the page you're linking to is about. Also, Google considers anchor text when indexing a page. So, a missing anchor represents a lost opportunity to optimize the performance of the linked-to page in search results. How to fix: Use anchor text for your links where it is necessary. The link text must give users and search engines at least a basic idea of what the target page is about. Also, use short but descriptive text. For more information, please see the "Use link wisely" section in Google's SEO Starter Guide https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/7451184?hl=en&ref_topic=9460495&authuser=0
siteaudit.issue.216.descAbout: This issue is triggered if a link (either external or internal) on your website has an empty or naked anchor (i.e., anchor that uses a raw URL), or anchor text only contains symbols. Although a missing anchor doesn't prevent users and crawlers from following a link, it makes it difficult to understand what the page you're linking to is about. Also, Google considers anchor text when indexing a page. So, a missing anchor represents a lost opportunity to optimize the performance of the linked-to page in search results.
siteaudit.issue.216.descFix: Use anchor text for your links where it is necessary. The link text must give users and search engines at least a basic idea of what the target page is about. Also, use short but descriptive text. For more information, please see the "Use link wisely" section in Google's SEO Starter Guide.

siteaudit.issue.217.title: Links with non-descriptive anchor text
siteaudit.issue.217.desc: About this issue: This issue is triggered if a non-descriptive anchor text is used for a link (either internal or external). An anchor is considered to be non-descriptive if it doesn’t give any idea of what the linked-to page is about, for example, “click here”, “right here”, etc. This type of anchor provides little value to users and search engines as it doesn't provide any information about the target page. Also, such anchors will offer little in terms of the target page’s ability to be indexed by search engines, and as a result, rank for relevant search requests. For more information on the criteria used to trigger this check, refer to kb article title. How to fix: To let users and search engines understand the meaning of the linked-to page, use a succinct anchor text that describes the page’s content. For best practices on how to optimize your anchor text, refer to the “Write good link text” section in Google’s Search Engine Optimization (SEO) Starter Guide https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/7451184?hl=en&ref_topic=9460495&authuser=0.
siteaudit.issue.217.descAbout: This issue is triggered if a non-descriptive anchor text is used for a link (either internal or external). An anchor is considered to be non-descriptive if it doesn’t give any idea of what the linked-to page is about, for example, “click here”, “right here”, etc. This type of anchor provides little value to users and search engines as it doesn't provide any information about the target page. Also, such anchors will offer little in terms of the target page’s ability to be indexed by search engines, and as a result, rank for relevant search requests. For more information on the criteria used to trigger this check, refer to “What are unoptimized anchors and how does Site Audit identify them?”.
siteaudit.issue.217.descFix: To let users and search engines understand the meaning of the linked-to page, use a succinct anchor text that describes the page’s content. For best practices on how to optimize your anchor text, refer to the “Write good link text” section in Google’s Search Engine Optimization (SEO) Starter Guide.

siteaudit.issue.218.title: External pages or resources with 403 HTTP status code
siteaudit.issue.218.desc: About this issue: This issue is triggered if a crawler gets a 403 code when trying to access an external webpage or resource via a link on your site. A 403 HTTP status code is returned if a user is not allowed to access the resource for some reason. In the case of crawlers, this usually means that a crawler is being blocked from accessing content at the server level. How to fix: Check that the page is available to browsers and search engines. To do this, follow a link in your browser and check the Google Search Console data. 1. If a page or resource is not available, contact the owner of the external website to restore deleted content or change the link on your page. 2. If a page is available but our bot is blocked from accessing it, you can ask the external website owner to unblock the page, so we can check all resources correctly. You can also hide this issue from your list.
siteaudit.issue.218.descAbout: This issue is triggered if a crawler gets a 403 code when trying to access an external webpage or resource via a link on your site. A 403 HTTP status code is returned if a user is not allowed to access the resource for some reason. In the case of crawlers, this usually means that a crawler is being blocked from accessing content at the server level.
siteaudit.issue.218.descFix:
Check that the page is available to browsers and search engines. To do this, follow a link in your browser and check the Google Search Console data.
- If a page or resource is not available, contact the owner of the external website to restore deleted content or change the link on your page
- If a page is available but our bot is blocked from accessing it, you can ask the external website owner to unblock the page, so we can check all resources correctly. You can also hide this issue from your list.

siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.0.title: Unknown language code
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.0.descrip: The language code in your hreflang attribute must be in ISO 639-1 format. Otherwise, Google will ignore your hreflang attribute.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.1.title: Unknown country code
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.1.descrip: The country code in your hreflang attribute must be in ISO 3166-1 Alpha 2 format. Otherwise, your hreflang attribute won’t function properly.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.2.title: Underscores used
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.2.descrip: Using underscores to separate language and country values in the hreflang attribute is not valid. Replace all underscores with hyphens.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.3.title: Invalid order of hreflang values
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.3.descrip: Values in your hreflang attribute are specified in reverse order. A language code must always precede a country code.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.4.title: Only country code is used
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.4.descrip: When using a country code, you must always provide a correct language code. Specifying a country code alone is not allowed.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.5.title: Conflicting hreflang and rel=canonical
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.5.descrip: The canonical tag on this page points to a different language URL. When using canonical tags on your website along with hreflang attributes, you should make sure to specify a self-referential canonical tag.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.6.title: Conflicting hreflang URLs
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.6.descrip:
If more than one URL is specified for the same language and country, search engines will ignore all of them.
Remove all conflicting hreflang URLs, and make sure that you only have one URL specified for a particular language and country in your hreflang attribute.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.7.title: No self-referencing hreflang
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.7.descrip:
If your page doesn’t contain a self-referencing hreflang in its set of hreflang attributes, those attributes may be ignored or interpreted incorrectly.
Include this page’s URL and language code in your set of hreflang attributes.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.8.title: Broken hreflang URL
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.8.descrip: If your hreflang link points to a URL that returns a 4xx or 5xx HTTP status code, it will be ignored by search engines. Either remove your hreflang or use a correct URL.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.9.title: Hreflang redirect
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.9.descrip: If your hreflang link points to a page that is redirected, the new page may not get indexed or even appear in search results. Change the hreflang URL to the URL of the new page, or eliminate the redirect.
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.10.title: Relative URL used
siteaudit.params.hreflangTypes.10.descri: If you're using relative or short URLs for your hreflang attributes, search engines will most likely interpret them incorrectly. If you'd like to avoid any problems, you should use absolute URLs in your hreflang attributes.

siteaudit.statistics.crawlDepth.point.to: Pages with a crawl depth of {number}: {amount}
siteaudit.statusCode.100.desc: This interim response indicates that everything so far is OK and that the client should continue with the request or ignore it if it is already finished.
siteaudit.statusCode.101.desc: This code is sent in response to an Upgrade: request header by the client, and indicates that the protocol the server is switching too. It was introduced to allow migration to an incompatible protocol version, and is not in common use.
siteaudit.statusCode.200.desc: The request has succeeded. The meaning of a success varies depending on the HTTP method.
siteaudit.statusCode.201.desc: The request has succeeded and a new resource has been created as a result of it. This is typically the response sent after a PUT request.
siteaudit.statusCode.202.desc: The request has been received but not yet acted upon. It is non-committal, meaning that there is no way in HTTP to later send an asynchronous response indicating the outcome of processing the request. It is intended for cases where another process or server handles the request, or for batch processing.
siteaudit.statusCode.203.desc: This response code means returned meta-information set is not exact set as available from the origin server, but collected from a local or a third party copy. Except this condition, 200 OK response should be preferred instead of this response.
siteaudit.statusCode.204.desc: There is no content to send for this request, but the headers may be useful. The user-agent may update its cached headers for this resource with the new ones.
siteaudit.statusCode.205.desc: This response code is sent after accomplishing request to tell user agent reset document view which sent this request.
siteaudit.statusCode.206.desc: This response code is used because of range header sent by the client to separate download into multiple streams.
siteaudit.statusCode.300.desc: The request has more than one possible responses. User-agent or user should choose one of them. There is no standardized way to choose one of the responses.
siteaudit.statusCode.301.desc: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed. Probably, new URI would be given in the response.
siteaudit.statusCode.302.desc: This response code means that URI of requested resource has been changed temporarily. New changes in the URI might be made in the future. Therefore, this same URI should be used by the client in future requests.
siteaudit.statusCode.303.desc: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with an GET request.
siteaudit.statusCode.304.desc: This is used for caching purposes. It is telling to client that response has not been modified. So, client can continue to use same cached version of response.
siteaudit.statusCode.305.desc: This means requested response must be accessed by a proxy. This response code is not largely supported because security reasons.
siteaudit.statusCode.306.desc: This response code is no longer used, it is just reserved currently. It was used in a previous version of the HTTP 1.1 specification.
siteaudit.statusCode.307.desc: Server sent this response to directing client to get requested resource to another URI with same method that used prior request. This has the same semantic than the 302 Found HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.
siteaudit.statusCode.308.desc: This means that the resource is now permanently located at another URI, specified by the Location: HTTP Response header. This has the same semantics as the 301 Moved Permanently HTTP response code, with the exception that the user agent must not change the HTTP method used: if a POST was used in the first request, a POST must be used in the second request.
siteaudit.statusCode.400.desc: This response means that server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax.
siteaudit.statusCode.401.desc: Authentication is needed to get requested response. This is similar to 403, but in this case, authentication is possible.
siteaudit.statusCode.402.desc: This response code is reserved for future use. Initial aim for creating this code was using it for digital payment systems however this is not used currently.
siteaudit.statusCode.403.desc: Client does not have access rights to the content so server is rejecting to give proper response.
siteaudit.statusCode.404.desc: Server can not find requested resource. This response code probably is most famous one due to its frequency to occur in web.
siteaudit.statusCode.405.desc: The request method is known by the server but has been disabled and cannot be used. The two mandatory methods, GET and HEAD, must never be disabled and should not return this error code.
siteaudit.statusCode.406.desc: This response is sent when the web server, after performing server-driven content negotiation, doesn't find any content following the criteria given by the user agent.
siteaudit.statusCode.407.desc: This is similar to 401 but authentication is needed to be done by a proxy.
siteaudit.statusCode.408.desc: This response is sent on an idle connection by some servers, even without any previous request by the client. It means that the server would like to shut down this unused connection. This response is used much more since some browsers, like Chrome or IE9, use HTTP preconnection mechanisms to speed up surfing (see bug 881804, which tracks the future implementation of such a mechanism in Firefox). Also note that some servers merely shut down the connection without sending this message.
siteaudit.statusCode.409.desc: This response would be sent when a request conflict with current state of server.
siteaudit.statusCode.410.desc: This response would be sent when requested content has been deleted from server.
siteaudit.statusCode.411.desc: Server rejected the request because the Content-Length header field is not defined and the server requires it.
siteaudit.statusCode.412.desc: The client has indicated preconditions in its headers which the server does not meet.
siteaudit.statusCode.413.desc: Request entity is larger than limits defined by server; the server might close the connection or return an Retry-After header field.
siteaudit.statusCode.414.desc: The URI requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
siteaudit.statusCode.415.desc: The media format of the requested data is not supported by the server, so the server is rejecting the request.
siteaudit.statusCode.416.desc: The range specified by the Range header field in the request can't be fulfilled; it's possible that the range is outside the size of the target URI's data.
siteaudit.statusCode.417.desc: This response code means the expectation indicated by the Expect request header field can't be met by the server.
siteaudit.statusCode.418.desc: Any attempt to brew coffee with a teapot should result in the error code "418 I'm a teapot". The resulting entity body MAY be short and stout.
siteaudit.statusCode.421.desc: The request was directed at a server that is not able to produce a response. This can be sent by a server that is not configured to produce responses for the combination of scheme and authority that are included in the request URI.
siteaudit.statusCode.426.desc: The server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol. The server MUST send an Upgrade header field in a 426 response to indicate the required protocol(s) (Section 6.7 of [RFC7230]).
siteaudit.statusCode.428.desc: The origin server requires the request to be conditional. Intended to prevent "the 'lost update' problem, where a client GETs a resource's state, modifies it, and PUTs it back to the server, when meanwhile a third party has modified the state on the server, leading to a conflict."
siteaudit.statusCode.429.desc: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting").
siteaudit.statusCode.431.desc: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large. The request MAY be resubmitted after reducing the size of the request header fields.
siteaudit.statusCode.500.desc: The server has encountered a situation it doesn't know how to handle.
siteaudit.statusCode.501.desc: The request method is not supported by the server and cannot be handled. The only methods that servers are required to support (and therefore that must not return this code) are GET and HEAD.
siteaudit.statusCode.502.desc: This error response means that the server, while working as a gateway to get a response needed to handle the request, got an invalid response.
siteaudit.statusCode.503.desc: The server is not ready to handle the request. Common causes are a server that is down for maintenance or that is overloaded. Note that together with this response, a user-friendly page explaining the problem should be sent. This responses should be used for temporary conditions and the Retry-After: HTTP header should, if possible, contain the estimated time before the recovery of the service. The webmaster must also take care about the caching-related headers that are sent along with this response, as these temporary condition responses should usually not be cached.
siteaudit.statusCode.504.desc: This error response is given when the server is acting as a gateway and cannot get a response in time.
siteaudit.statusCode.505.desc: The HTTP version used in the request is not supported by the server.
siteaudit.statusCode.506.desc: The server has an internal configuration error: transparent content negotiation for the request results in a circular reference.
siteaudit.statusCode.507.desc: This HTTP status code means that the server is unable to store the representation needed to complete the request.
siteaudit.statusCode.511.desc: The 511 status code indicates that the client needs to authenticate to gain network access.

siteaudit.statistics.list.markups.title: Markup
siteaudit.statistics.list.markups.desc: Using markup data on your webpages is a powerful way to increase your visibility to search engines and gain higher click-through rates, which may in turn lead to better rankings.
siteaudit.statistics.list.crawlDepth.des:
A page’s crawl depth is the number of clicks required for users and search engine crawlers to reach it via its corresponding homepage. From an SEO perspective, an excessive crawl depth may pose a great threat to your optimization efforts, as both crawlers and users are less likely to reach deep pages.

For this reason, pages that contain important content should be no more than 3 clicks away from your homepage.
siteaudit.statistics.list.statusCode.des:
HTTP status codes refer to requests made to a web server by search engines or website visitors. Having a lot of pages on your site that return 4xx or 5xx status codes can negatively affect both your site's user experience and its crawlability, which could lead to a drop in traffic.

If you want your website to rank well, it's important to understand, manage and monitor your HTTP status codes.
siteaudit.statistics.list.canonicalizati: To prevent duplicate content issues, we encourage you to use a rel="canonical" link element pointing to your original webpage for each webpage with similar or identical content. You should also consider adding a self-referencing canonical link to your original website's pages, as it is a good way to combat scrapers and prevent them from outranking you for your own content.
siteaudit.statistics.list.ampLinks.title: AMP Links
siteaudit.statistics.list.ampLinks.desc:
Google is obviously giving preference to pages created with its new technology, known as AMP, by placing them at the top of mobile search results in the Top Stories area.

So, if you’d like to win Google’s favor and see your pages in Google’s Top Stories, you should definitely consider creating Accelerated Mobile Pages.
siteaudit.statistics.list.sitemap.title: Sitemap vs Crawled Pages
siteaudit.statistics.list.sitemap.desc: If the number of pages specified in your sitemap.xml doesn’t match the number of crawled pages, this may be a sign that your website has a bad crawlability due to poor linking or other technical issues. To make sure that search engines can efficiently crawl and index your website, you should keep an eye on the number of pages in your sitemap.xml and the number of pages we crawled.
siteaudit.statistics.list.iiLinks.title: Incoming Internal Links
siteaudit.statistics.list.iiLinks.desc: Having very few incoming internal links means very few visits, or even none, and fewer chances of placing in search results. It is a good practice to add more incoming internal links to pages with useful content. That way, you can rest assured that users and search engines will never miss them.

siteaudit.statistics.list.hreflang.desc: If you're running a multilingual website, it is necessary to help users from other countries find your content in the language that is most appropriate for them. This is where the hreflang (rel="alternate" hreflang="x") attribute comes in handy. Utilizing this attribute on your website’s pages tells search engines which pages should be shown to visitors based on their location. That way, you can be sure that your users will always land on the correct language version of your website.

siteaudit.robots.dropdown.about.title: About robots.txt
siteaudit.robots.dropdown.about.content: A robots.txt file is used to instruct search engines what content on your website they should crawl. Even a minor change to this file may negatively affect your website's indexability. Unplanned and ill-considered updates may dramatically damage your website's rankings.

Avoid chaining critical requests
Critical request chains are a sequence of requests that depend on previous requests and are important for page rendering. The longer the chain length, the slower your page load performance.

<0>Here are a few ways to reduce the negative impact of critical request chains:</0><1><2>Minimize the number of critical resources (eliminate them, defer their download, mark them as “async”, etc…)</2><3>Optimize the number of critical bytes to reduce the download time</3><4>Optimize the order in which the remaining critical resources are loaded (download all critical assets as early as possible to shorten the critical path length).</4></1><5>For more information, please see this <6>web.dev article</6>.</5><7>Use PageSpeed Insights to identify the сritical request chains that contribute most to your page’s load performance.</7>
Use video formats for animated content
GIFs typically use more bandwidth than video formats and can add to the load time of animated content. By converting GIFs to video formats, you can cut down on the load time of these resources.

<0>There are various online tools to help you convert GIFs to video formats. However, GIFs have several advantages over videos: they play automatically, loop continuously, and are silent. You can recreate these behaviors using the <video> element.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Use Pagespeed Insights to see if your page has large GIFs that are considered to be inefficient for delivering animated content.</1>
Ensure text remains visible during webfont load

The font used when displaying text content on a webpage usually needs to be loaded to the page as well. Custom fonts tend to be large files that take a while to load. Some browsers will hide the text until the font loads, causing a <0>flash of invisible text (FOIT)</0>. When the text on the page isn’t immediately visible, it can create a bad user experience.

<0>The easiest way to make the text visible while the custom font loads is to use font-display: swap in your @font-face style. This will solve the FOIT issue for most modern browsers.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>.</1>
Preload largest contentful paint image

<0>Images can take a long time to load especially if they are loading after other non-critical assets. In certain cases, you may identify an image file as a resource that needs to be loaded before others.</0><1>This audit fails when such an image is located in the largest contentful element on the page, and resolving this issue should have a positive impact on the page’s LCP.</1>

<0>Use the <link rel="preload"> HTML tag to tell the browser to load images before the other non-critical assets on the page.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Run PageSpeed Insights to find images used by the LCP element in order to improve your LCP time.</1>
Avoid multiple page redirects

When a browser lands on a page or resource that has been redirected, the server will return an HTTP response telling it to move to the new page. The browser then has to make another request for that new page. This response-request cycle can significantly delay the load time of the page or resource.

<0>Update all incoming links so they direct the browser to the current pages’ URLs. This eliminates the need for redirects and can greatly improve load time, resulting in a more satisfactory user experience. You can also use the Internal Linking report in the Site Audit’s Overview to find internal links with redirects throughout your site’s navigation.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what redirects introduce additional delays before the page can be loaded.</1>
Eliminate render-blocking resources

Most webpages use scripts and stylesheets to enable user interaction with elements of the page and enhance the appearance of the page’s content. However, scripts and stylesheets can take a long time to load, or prevent the page from loading fully, which ultimately worsens the experience of your visitors.

<0>The first thing you need to do is to understand which resources are critical and which are not. Then consider delivering critical JS/CSS inline and deferring all non-critical JS/styles.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>.</1><3>Use PageSpeed Insights to find resources that are blocking the first paint of your page.</3>
Reduce server response time

<0>Server response time measures how long it takes to receive data from the server. When a user is coming to a page, their browser will send a request to the server to get information. The server receives and processes the request, and returns the page content. Slow server responses cause long page loads, which provides users with a negative experience.</0><1>This audit fails if the server response time is more than 600ms.</1>

<0>Identify core conceptual tasks that your server must execute to return information on a page in a timely manner, and then fix issues causing slow server responses. Here are the key ones:</0><1><2>Server application logic</2><3>Server framework issues</3><4>Slow server database</4><5>Slow or outdated server hardware (CPU/memory)</5></1><6>For more information, please see <7>this web.dev article</7>. Use PageSpeed Insights to identify the longest tasks that most affect the server response time.</6>
Avoid Enormous Network Payloads

<0>An enormous network payload means that the size of network requests being made is substantially large, causing longer load times for your page. These large requests negatively impact site performance and user experience, especially on mobile devices.</0><1>The audit fails if the total size of the page’s network requests exceeds 5,000 KiB.</1>

<0>To avoid enormous payloads, perform the following:</0><1><2>Keep the total size of requests under 1,600KiB.</2><3>Defer requests until they’re needed</3><4>Compress payloads</4><5>Compress JPEG images or convert them to WebP</5><6>Cache requests</6></1><7>For more information, please see <8>this web.dev article</8>. Use PageSpeed Insights to identify the largest resources of the page.</7>
Minify CSS

The larger CSS files are, the longer they take to download, thereby negatively affecting the page performance. Minification helps reduce their size by removing unnecessary lines, white space, and comments from the source code. This will decrease your page load time, provide a better user experience, and improve your search engine rankings.

<0>Minify CSS files. This can be done manually or with the help of online services.</0><1>If your webpage uses CSS files that are hosted on an external site, contact the website owner and ask them to minify their files.</1><2>For more information, see our Site Performance report or read <3>this web.dev article</3>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what CSS files need to be minified and reduce network payload sizes.</2>
Minify Javascript

The larger your JavaScript files are, the longer they take to be downloaded, parsed, and executed by a browser, thereby negatively affecting the page performance. Minification helps reduce their size by removing unnecessary lines, white space, and comments from the source code. This will decrease your page load time, provide a better user experience, and improve your search engine rankings.

<0>Minify your JavaScript files. If your webpage uses JS files that are hosted on an external site, contact the website owner and ask them to minify their files.</0><1>For more information, see our Site Performance report or read <2>this web.dev article</2>.</1>
Remove Unused CSS

Unused CSS files on your page are consuming unnecessary bytes and network activity. These files are being downloaded, parsed, and processed without any functional purpose and can potentially slow down browsers.

<0>Identify and delete CSS files that are not being used. Inline critical CSS files and defer non-critical ones: place critical CSS inside the <style> tag in the head of the HTML page, and then load the rest of the styles using the preload link.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Use PageSpeed Insights to identify unused CSS files.</1>
Remove Unused JavaScript

Unused JavaScript present on your page slows down your page load speed. This file is being downloaded, parsed, and processed by a browser without any functional purpose. Unused code is wasteful, decreases page load speed, and could be causing mobile users to waste more data.

<0>Remove unused JavaScript from your page if it is not needed or critical to the page’s function. You can use the <1>Coverage tab</1> to help you with this issue.</0><2>For more information, please see <3>this web.dev article</3>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what plugins can be reduced or switched.</2>
Preconnect to Required Origins

If key requests on your page are not prioritizing fetch requests with <link rel="preconnect">, it will slow down network connections, in particular secure connections. This is often related to important third-party origins. The <link rel="preconnect"> informs the browser that your page intends to establish a connection to another origin, and that you’d like the process to start as soon as possible.

<0>Use the preconnect or dns-prefetch resource hints on your page as a way to fix these issues, allowing connections to third-party origins to be made promptly.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find connections that should be used sparingly and only to the most important origins.</1>
Enable Text Compression

It is always useful to compress text and text-based resources on your page to decrease network byte consumption. Compression allows you to reduce the size of resources like HTML, CSS and JavaScript, making them download faster. For a detailed look into this issue, run PageSpeed Insights.

<0>Enable text compression on a server level. Use the Accept-Encoding HTTP request header to indicate the compression algorithms that are supported. Popular and recommended compression algorithms include Brotli and GZIP. For more information, see our Site Performance report and read <1>this web.dev article</1>.</0><2>Use PageSpeed Insights to find more details about this issue.</2>
Avoid an excessive DOM size

The Document Object Model (DOM) refers to all the elements (nodes) that make up the HTML structure of the webpage. If your page has too many HTML elements or they are nested too deeply, the browser will need more time and power to process them, resulting in slow page performance and poor user experience.

<0>Create DOM nodes only when needed, and delete the ones that are no longer necessary. Also, you can try to remove the undisplayed nodes from the initially loaded document and only create them after relevant user interaction, such as a scroll or a button click.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this web.dev article</2>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what elements on your page increase memory usage, cause longer style calculations, and produce costly layout reflows.</1>
Remove duplicate modules in JavaScript bundles

JavaScript bundles are usually built by importing code from popular libraries, dependencies, and packages. As a result, your page can inherit duplicate modules from different sources. This slows down the page load and worsens the user experience as the browser has to download, parse, and execute unnecessary extra code.

<0>One of the main ways to avoid duplication of JavaScript modules is to integrate good site-building practices in your development workflow. To identify duplicate modules, use <1>webpack-stats-duplicates</1>.</0><2>For more information, please see <3>this article</3>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find large, duplicate JavaScript modules from bundles that can be removed.</2>
Avoid serving legacy JavaScript to modern browsers

Although most modern browsers support the latest JavaScript standard (ES6 or ES2015+), some developers still use legacy JavaScript (ES5 standard) to support old browsers. This is done through polyfills, a piece of code allowing legacy browsers to use the new functionality. However, serving lots of unnecessary JS to users on modern browsers increases the time of the page load, and may even lead to a situation when none of the code will run.

<0>To fix this issue, implement modern feature detection using <script type="module"> and <script nomodule>.</0><1>Browsers that support <script type="module"> also support most of the ES6 features. This will let you load regular JavaScript files with ES6 features and know that the browser can handle it.</1><2>For browsers that do not support <script type="module">, use the translated ES5 code. That way, you will always serve modern code to modern browsers.</2><3>For more information, please see <4>this article</4>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find URLs of the resources that use legacy JS code.</3>
Lazy load third-party resources with facades

Third-party resources (e.g., ads, videos, social media widgets) are loaded as soon as the page loads. This can slow down your page due to a number of reasons. The common way to reduce the negative impact of these resources on the page performance is to replace them with a facade (a static element that has less impact on the page load) until they are required.

<0>Load a page with a static element that looks similar to the actual embedded third-party instead of embedding it into your HTML. The interaction pattern should look as follows:</0><1><2>On load: Add a facade to the page</2><3>On mouseover: The facade preconnects to third-party resources</3><4>On click: The facade replaces itself with the third-party product.</4></1><5>For more information, please see <6>this web.dev article</6>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what third-party resources on your page need to be lazy-loaded and replaced with facades.</5>
Reduce the impact of third-party code

A third-party script is any script hosted on a domain that’s different from your domain. Common examples of these scripts are social media buttons, analytics scripts, A/B testing scripts, etc. As the page loads, Lighthouse calculates how long each of the third-party scripts blocks the main thread. If the total blocking time is greater than 250 ms, the audit fails.

<0>If a third-party script is slowing down your page load, you can do either of the following:</0><1><2>Remove it if it is not required for your site’s functionality.</2><3>Optimize the loading process.</3></1><4>For more information on how to optimize the loading process of third-party scripts, please see <5>this article</5>.</4>
Reduce JavaScript execution time

When your JavaScript takes a long time to execute, it slows down your page performance in several ways. For example, if your page runs a lot of code before it’s really needed, that delays Time To Interactive, which is one of the key metrics related to how users perceive your page speed. For more information, please see <0>this article</0>.

<0>To speed up JavaScript execution, implement code splitting when it makes sense to do so. You can also minify and compress your code.</0><1>For more information on how to speed up JavaScript execution, please see <2>this article</2>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find which JS files are considered for reducing the time spent parsing, compiling, and executing.</1>
Minimize main thread work

The main thread is where a browser processes tasks required for displaying a page, like parsing HTML and CSS, executing JavaScript, and building DOM. Any time the main thread is busy doing something else, your webpage may not respond to user interactions, leading to a bad experience.

<0>Here are the key steps you should follow:</0><1><2>Find out which category of work keeps the main thread busy during the page load.</2><3>Identify tasks that are taking the most time using the Chrome DevTools Performance panel.</3><4>Try to defer or remove unnecessary work that blocks the main thread for more than 50ms.</4></1><5>For more information, please see <6>this article</6>. Use PageSpeedInsights to find which categories take more time than others.</5>
Image elements do not have explicit width and height

Setting the width and height attributes for your images is necessary if you want to prevent content layout shifts during the page load. This will allow a browser to allocate the required amount of space for your images. Alternatively, you can use CSS for the same purpose.

<0>To ensure that sufficient spacing is reserved for your images, add width and height attributes to your tags. Modern browsers will automatically calculate an aspect ratio for an image based on the provided attributes.<1>For more information, please see <2>this article. Use PageSpeed Insights to find failing elements.
Avoid non-composited animations

<0>A non-composited animation is any animation run during the CSS and JavaScript execution and on the main thread, which increases the latter’s work and can cause layout shifts.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this article</2>.</1>

<0>To fix this audit, always perform composited animations.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>High Performance Animations</2> and <3>Promote elements that move or fade</3>. Use PageSpeed Insights to find what elements are not composited and increase CLS.</1>
Preload key requests

<0>When a user visits a page, their browser starts loading resources in a certain order. If critical resources of your page are not prioritized with <link rel="preload">, they may be discovered and downloaded late, increasing the page load time. The <link rel="preload"> allows you to instruct a browser to download important resources as soon as possible.</0><1>For more information, please see <2>this article</2>.</1>
<0>Add <link rel="preload"> to the HTML header of your page.</0><1>Use PageSpeed Insights to identify resources that should be preloaded.</1>

siteaudit.crawlability.text.p1: Monitoring whether search engine crawlers can properly access and index your website is one of the key aspects of successful search engine optimization. No matter how much time you spend creating fabulous content or acquiring high-quality backlinks, they will never take your site to the first position if web crawlers can't access it.
siteaudit.crawlability.text.p2: We know there are a lot of factors that can impede effective crawlability, and it may be a tough task to detect if your website is crawler-friendly. That's why we want to create a new Crawlability report to help you quickly pinpoint and fix all crawlability and indexability issues, so you can rest assured that your optimization efforts won't be in vain.

siteaudit.crawlability.blocks.budget.too:
Your crawl budget is the maximum number of times search engines can crawl your website within a specific time frame. It is assigned to every website based on its load speed, the quality of its pages, and how often its content is updated. It is very important to use it efficiently and avoid any waste because once your crawl budget runs out, search engines will stop crawling your website any further, and they won’t even access your important content.

Factoring in the most common reasons for a wasted crawl budget, we help you quickly and easily identify all pages that negatively affect your website’s crawlability, and, as a result, reduce your crawl budget.
siteaudit.crawlability.blocks.budget.opt: There are no issues that can reduce your website’s crawl budget.
siteaudit.crawlability.blocks.more.title: To get more data concerning your website's crawlability, view your report in PDF format.
siteaudit.crawlability.blocks.more.detai: The PDF report allows you to view detailed crawlability information, e.g., Pages Crawl Depth, Incoming Internal Links, Sitemap vs. Crawled pages, and HTTP Status Code.
We build your site structure based on the pages we crawl. If it differs from your actual site structure, please check your campaign settings or increase the limit of crawled pages.
